article.title: Distributed fiber sparse-wideband vibration sensing by sub-Nyquist random sampling

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is true about the Power Spectral Density (PSD) shown in Figure 1?
choices: Figure 1(a) represents the PSD of additive random sampling pulse.
Figure 1(b) shows periodic replicas of Wx(f)*Ww(f) with period fs.
Figure 1(a) depicts the PSD of a uniform sampling pulse, while Figure 1(b) illustrates the PSD of an additive random sampling pulse.
Both Figure 1(a) and 1(b) show a continuous spectrum without any distinct peaks.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 explores the effects of different sampling parameters on SNARS performance. What can be concluded from these results?
choices: Increasing the maximum sampling interval factor (kt) always improves the SNR.
The AWG sampling rate (fs-awg) has negligible impact on the frequency aliasing effect.
A higher sampling length (N) and a larger analytical frequency resolution factor (ka) generally lead to a better SNR, indicating improved signal reconstruction.
The optimal sampling parameters are independent of the specific application and signal characteristics.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 compares Nyquist Uniform Sampling (NUS) and Sub-Nyquist Additive Random Sampling (SNARS) in a φ-OTDR system. Which statement accurately reflects the information presented?
choices: Figure 3(d) shows regularly spaced sampling traces characteristic of NUS, while Figure 3(e) depicts the randomly distributed sampling instances of SNARS.
Both NUS and SNARS utilize the same sampling interval, as shown in Figure 3(b) and 3(c).
Figure 3(a) illustrates the setup where both NUS and SNARS employ identical lengths for sensing fibers A and B.
The intensity response of the fiber to external phase modulation remains constant for both NUS and SNARS irrespective of the sampling method.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 analyzes the vibration signal captured using NUS and SNARS. What insight can be drawn from the comparison of their performance?
choices: The PSD spectrum of SNARS data in Figure 4(d) is free from any alias noise, making it superior to NUS.
NUS fails to capture the frequency components of the signal, as evident from Figure 4(c).
The reconstructed signal from SNARS data in Figure 4(a) deviates significantly from the actual signal.

Despite the presence of alias noise in SNARS (Figure 4(d)), signal reconstruction successfully identifies the frequency components, demonstrating its ability to recover sparse signals even with a lower sampling rate.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 compares NUS and SNARS in a long-range φ-OTDR system. What conclusion can be derived from the presented results?
choices: Both NUS and SNARS exhibit similar performance in identifying the frequency components of the wideband sparse signal.
Figure 5(f) demonstrates that NUS successfully avoids aliasing effects in the long-range sensing scenario.

While NUS suffers from aliasing in the long-range setup (Figure 5(f)), SNARS, despite alias noise (Figure 5(g)), enables identification and reconstruction of the signal (Figure 5(h)), highlighting its advantage for sparse wideband signal detection in long-range φ-OTDR systems.
The reconstructed signal in Figure 5(h) obtained from SNARS data shows no resemblance to the actual signal.
